Thanks :tada:

bors merge

```suggestion
theorem count_of_forall (hp : âˆ€ n, p n) : count p = id := by
```

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem count_true : count (fun _ â†¦ True) = id := count_of_forall fun _ â†¦ trivial
```

```suggestion
theorem count_of_forall_not (hp : âˆ€ n, Â¬p n) : count p = 0 := by
```

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem count_false : count (fun _ â†¦ False) = 0 := count_of_forall_not fun _ â†¦ id
```

I strongly advise you to state your results to be about applied functions. I too at some point got into the habit of writing equality when both sides are nicely named, but it turns out to be really impractical with `rw`. Eg if you `rw [count_true]` on
`count p a + count p b = a + b` then you get `id a + id b` which is annoying because
* You have to get rid of the `id`, and in particular you can't use `count_true` to rewrite backwards
* You might have wanted to rewrite only one of the two occurrences

In short, I suggest proving
```suggestion
theorem count_true (hp : âˆ€ n, p n) (n : â„•) : count p n = n := by
```
instead

Updated (the applied versions have slightly weaker hypotheses).

I'm tempted to keep the `simp` versions un-applied since `True` usually only shows up mid-`simp` and this way it will simp expressions like `Nat.nth (fun _ â†¦ True) '' S` (which was my original motivation)

I see. It might or might not make sense to use `Set.image_eta` (unsure what it's called) explicitly in your simp call instead. It's the lemma stating `f '' s = (fun x => f x) '' s`, and it's really useful for exactly this kind of situation where your function is underapplied.

The slightly unwieldy thing about that is that it requires looking up a lemma for each potential situation, e.g. for `Finset` instead of `Set`, etc; `eta_expand` works in general but is a bit awkward to do in the middle of a simp.

Occasionally I see `_ = id` simp-lemmas that have a corresponding `_ x = x` (sometimes also simp) lemma called `..._apply`; is that an OK pattern?
Depends what the lemmas are, but can you tell that your approach requires many more lemmas than mine?
I suspect the lemmas you are talking about are about bundled morphisms

> I suspect the lemmas you are talking about are about bundled morphisms

Many of the hits on Loogle are indeed; sometimes they're plain functions e.g. [docs#Set.image_id_eq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Image.html#Set.image_id_eq), [docs#Set.preimage_id_eq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Image.html#Set.preimage_id_eq).

Either way, I'm happy to just change these to the applied versions. I do think it makes the simp UX slightly worse but it's easy enough to work around.
I see where you got the names from. These lemmas are misnamed
... and this one is misstated. Feel free to fix in this PR!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: `@[simp]` `Nat.count` / `Nat.nth` of `fun _ â†¦ True`, `False`
